topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0: Backup and Restore

body.p: This page explains how to backup and restore HPE OpenStack Carrier Grade and HPE DCN configuration files in the event of catastrophic failure. The page also explains how to recover the Percona XtraDB cluster on the cloud controllers in the event of a database corruption.

HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade includes a backup and restore application called Attis which you can use to backup and restore essential system files and components of the non-KVM cloud. Attis is automatically installed on each of the controller nodes in the non-KVM region. Attis uses a command line interface. For more information, see Attis Backup and Restore CLI.

The installation also includes the Percona XtraDB application, which takes care of synchronization of the data between nodes if one of the nodes goes down and comes back later. You can use Percona XtraDB to backup and restore the MySQL nodes that the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade installs in the non-KVM region.

section.title: IMPORTANT: Attis Administrator Responsibilites for Protecting Credentials
section.p: Attis performs encrypted backup and restore of system data. The key for encryption and decryption is stored in the Attis configuration file on each controller node. If this key is lost, your backups can not be restored. Consider storing the backup encryption key separately from your cloud infrastructure, in addition to the copy stored on each controller node.

Be aware that keys and passwords for other OpenStack services are stored in configuration files on cloud infrastructure nodes, protected by filesystem controls. Protect servers from unauthorized access and protect against exposure of credentials in configuration files. Attis backups contain copies of these credentials as well, protected from snooping via backup encryption, but exposure of the Attis backup key could result in unauthorized exposure of credentials stored in backups.

section.title: What gets backed up
section.p: The following components can be backed up and restored:

ul.li: Percona XtraDB cluster on the controllers.
Percona XtraDB cluster on the VSD host.
All files under the /opt/ folder on the HLM host. This backs up all the installed code/configuration and also h* installation scripts.
All files under the /root/ folder on the HLM host. This backs up all the source code, packages, hlinux netboot, infra-ansible-playbooks, SSH keys, as well as cloud folders.
bog.cfg and config.cfg files on the VSC switch.
KVM-region backups from the backup utility
MySQL databases and Neutron, Nova, Ironic files under /etc on the baremetal controller (Sacramento deployments only)

section.p: Important: Do not store backup of the JSON files inside your cloud directory or any where inside the /var/hlm/clouds directory. You can create a backup folder on /root/ directory or on a remote system.

section.title: When to perform backups
section.p: We recommend performing regular backups, preferably hourly, and especially after changing the appliances configuration and before and after updating HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade software.
Additionally, you should create a backup from HLM VM as follows:

ul.li: when the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade installation is complete,
when any change is made to the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade components,
after syncing the files on the HLM VM. The files should be synced periodically using a tool appropriate for your environment.

section.title: When to restore
section.p: You should restore the HLM VM if there are any issues with the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade components, for example:

ul.li: there is any problem with a VM;
there is any problem in the operating system level;
there is any problem with the installation that cannot be corrected.
when two controllers have failed. HA Services are not guaranteed to be resilient after a second failure.

section.p: Important: During the restore process the original HLM VM will be deleted from the HLM host.

section.title: Backup and Restore the MySQL cluster
section.p: This section deals with the disaster recovery scenarios of the three node MySQL cluster (Percona XtraDB Cluster) that runs in cloud controller nodes. The HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade backup/restore process includes the MySQL cluster.

If an entire cluster goes down, due to an issue (such as data corruption or MySQL defect), and the cluster does not come back up, you must restore the cluster to a previous well-known state (backup) and start the cluster from that point.
You should take full backups of the MySQL cluster frequently, such as on a daily basis. Backing up the node on any single controller will backup the full cluster.

If the full cluster goes down or some data corruption occurs, delete the current data in all of the three nodes of MySQL and restore the backup copy on the same node from which backup was taken. Then, bootstrap the cluster and bring up rest of the nodes to synchronize the data with the recovered node of cluster.

section.title: Backup and Restore CLI
section.p: For more information on the Attis backup and restore CLI see Backup and Restore CLI.

section.title: Backing up the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade
section.p: To back up an HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade appliance (for example, the lifecycle manager, a controller, the VSC, the VSD and so forth), use the following steps:

ol.li: Authenticate using the source stackrc command or export the variables manually:export OS_PASSWORD=<your_os_password> export OS_USERNAME=admin export OS_TENANT_NAME=admin export OS_AUTH_URL=<your_os_auth_url>

Execute the following command to start the backup:attis backup --config-id CONFIG_ID --backup_type BACKUP_TYPE
Where
config-id CONFIG_ID authenticates using the ID configuration file.
backup_type BACKUP_TYPE is full or incremental. Full backup is the default.

section.title: Restore the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade
section.p: To restore an HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade appliance (for example, the lifecycle manager, a controller, the VSC, the VSD and so forth), use the following steps:

ol.li: Log in to the controller as cghelion user. The default password is cghelion.
Execute the following commands to change to the Attis user:sudo -i su attis

Execute the following command on all three controllers to copy the Attis public key to the VSD authorized_keys file: ssh-copy-id vsd_user@vsd_addressThe vsd_address can be found in the /etc/attis/dcn.lst file: cat /etc/attis/dcn.lst

Authenticate using export variables:export OS_TENANT_NAME=admin export OS_USERNAME=admin export OS_PASSWORD=1234 export OS_AUTH_URL=http://127.0.0.1:5000/v2.0Optionally you can pass the authentication values when you execute a CLI command --os-tenant-name "admin" --os-username "admin" --os-password "1234" --os-auth-url "http://127.0.0.1:5000/v2.0"

Execute the following command to start the backup:attis restore --config-id CONFIG_ID --backup-id BACKUP_ID
Where
config-id CONFIG_ID authenticates using the ID configuration file.
backup-id BACKUP_ID is the ID of the backup from which you want to perform the restore. Use the attis backuplog command to get a list of backup jobs.

section.title: Post-Restore Tasks
section.p: After restoring, perform these tasks as required:
SSH to VSD node and execute the following command after restoring VSD:service vsd restart

ol.li: After restore job is complete, from the HLM host, SSH to the compute proxy nodes.
Execute the following command to restart the Compute (Nova) service service nova-compute restart
